word.entryDescription: a profession that you do for a long time
word.entryExample: Craig does not have a permanent career in mind.

word.entryDescription: having no worries, problems or responsibilities
word.entryExample: She never worries about tomorrow and her carefree style of life makes her many friends.

word.entryDescription: goods which are being transported, usually in large quantities
word.entryExample: The first successful import of meat to the UK was a cargo of lamb from New Zealand, in 1882 – it took 92 days!

word.entryDescription: a large thick covering for the floor
word.entryExample: There's a blue carpet in my bedroom.

word.entryDescription: a long thin orange vegetable which grows underground
word.entryExample: Can I give the rabbit a carrot?

word.entryDescription: to continue
word.entryExample: If you decide to carry on working with me, I promise to be more patient.

word.entryDescription: luggage of a size and weight suitable for being carried onto an airplane by a passenger
word.entryExample: The maximum weight for a carry-on bag is 10 kg.

word.entryDescription: a box made from cardboard or plastic in which drinks are sold
word.entryExample: There's some milk and a carton of juice.

word.entryDescription: an often short film with moving images that are drawn; or a set of drawings that tell a funny story, especially in a newspaper or a magazine
word.entryExample: My brother's really into cartoons – he watches them on TV, he buys magazines, and he loves to see them at the cinema.

word.entryDescription: (=ink cartridge) a small container designed to be inserted into a larger piece of equipment to make it work
word.entryExample: Our printer has run out of ink again. We need to buy a new cartridge.

word.entryDescription: made out of stone or wood
word.entryExample: Each statue was carved out of stone and moved to the edge of the island.

word.entryDescription: a decorative or protective container
word.entryExample: Why did Tony buy a case for his smartphone?

word.entryDescription: a problem dealt with by a court; a crime that is being investigated
word.entryExample: The case can be solved and the criminal arrested and convicted with very little investigation.

word.entryDescription: money in the form of notes and coins
word.entryExample: If you shop in a street market, they won't take debit or credit cards – you'll need cash.

word.entryDescription: somebody whose job is to give and take money in a shop or bank
word.entryExample: They are looking for cashiers at the new supermarket.

word.entryDescription: a machine at a bank, in a shopping centre, etc from which you get money by using a special plastic card
word.entryExample: I need to get to the cashpoint because I've run out of money.

word.entryDescription: all the actors or performers in a film, play, programme, etc
word.entryExample: The chorus, an all-male cast of singers and dancers wearing masks, performed in a semi-circle known as an orchestra.

word.entryDescription: a big old building which was built for defence
word.entryExample: There was a big old castle nearby.

word.entryDescription: not formal; having a relaxed or relaxing quality
word.entryExample: I usually wear casual clothes like jeans or sportswear.

word.entryDescription: a furry animal with a long tail, that people often keep as a pet
word.entryExample: Cats like to drink milk.

word.entryDescription: causing a great deal of damage
word.entryExample: Doing nothing will have catastrophic effects, the report claims, and it urges world leaders to change their policies.

word.entryDescription: to take a fish out of water with a fishing rod (a long stick with a hook on the end)
word.entryExample: He's trying to catch a fish.

word.entryDescription: to be in time for a plane and get on it
word.entryExample: We catch a plane when we go on holiday.

word.entryDescription: a very big church
word.entryExample: They visited the Gaudi cathedral.

word.entryDescription: a long raised structure along which models walk in a fashion show
word.entryExample: Rivets and studs have made it onto the catwalk as details with attitude.

word.entryDescription: a large natural hole in the ground, particularly in a hill or cliff
word.entryExample: Harry enjoyed sleeping in the cave.

word.entryDescription: going into caves underground and exploring them
word.entryExample: I was a bit worried about going caving at first because I hate small spaces.

word.entryDescription: a small round flat piece of plastic on which music or data can be stored
word.entryExample: I would love a music CD for my birthday present.

word.entryDescription: a device used for playing music CDs
word.entryExample: This CD player is great because it can also play MP3s.

word.entryDescription: the surface at the top of a room, opposite the floor
word.entryExample: I'd love to live in a house with windows all the way from the ceiling to the floor.

word.entryDescription: to do something special and enjoyable to show that an event, occasion, achievement, etc is important
word.entryExample: We will go to the pizza restaurant to celebrate.

word.entryDescription: an event at which something is celebrated, or the act of celebrating something
word.entryExample: Thank you very much for inviting us to your wedding celebration.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'celebrities') somebody who becomes famous by being on television, in films, in newspapers, etc
word.entryExample: Sometimes cosplayers become celebrities – just like the actors whose characters they are imitating.

word.entryDescription: a unit for measuring length; one hundredth of a metre
word.entryExample: In some areas the snow is up to twenty centimetres deep, and many roads are closed.

word.entryDescription: a way of warming a building using water or air that is sent all around the building in pipes
word.entryExample: Treehouses don't have central heating.

word.entryDescription: the area right in the middle of a town or city
word.entryExample: How and why do you travel in the city centre?

word.entryDescription: a place where some kind of activity is concentrated or the middle of a space or area
word.entryExample: How far is it from the nearest shopping centre?

word.entryDescription: a plant grown for its grain or food made from this grain
word.entryExample: Cereal generally comes in cardboard boxes.

word.entryDescription: a formal event or special set of actions which takes place on a certain, often important, occasion
word.entryExample: The flag starts to fly in the Olympic stadium at the start of the opening ceremony.

word.entryDescription: an official document which confirms that particular information is true; or an official document confirming that you have completed a course of study
word.entryExample: I needed to show my birth certificate when I applied for a passport.

word.entryDescription: one of a group of shops run by the same company, usually looking the same and offering similar things
word.entryExample: John says that it's unusual for towns in America to have no chain stores.

word.entryDescription: a thing with a back and four legs that you sit on
word.entryExample: In the kitchen there's a table and four chairs.

word.entryDescription: a difficult task that tests you physically or mentally
word.entryExample: Take up the challenge of a new sport!

word.entryDescription: a woman whose job is to clean bedrooms in a hotel, guesthouse, etc
word.entryExample: Please wait while the chambermaid cleans the room.

word.entryDescription: the winner of a sporting competition
word.entryExample: Not everyone can be a Paralympics champion.

word.entryDescription: the British government minister responsible for economic and financial matters, or a very high ranking official in some other governments and in universities
word.entryExample: Athens' money paid jurors and chancellors, built a navy and maintained the army.

word.entryDescription: to become different or to make something different
word.entryExample: You should change your clothes!

word.entryDescription: the act/fact of changing/being changed
word.entryExample: I love to have a holiday on a quiet desert island, because I like a change from the noise of the city.

word.entryDescription: coins of low denomination or money returned when the sum offered in payment is larger than the price of a product
word.entryExample: Thank you. Here's your change and your receipt.

word.entryDescription: a room where you can change your clothes in, especially before playing sports, going swimming, etc.
word.entryExample: I wish these changing rooms were bigger.
